response_text: It definitely takes a lot of individual and team discipline but it can be very rewarding. It is not hard STEM skill focused at all; there is barely any advanced calculus or physics or anything like that. It's a pretty good course but in my opinion the first few weeks were quite boring. Do NOT take the 8:30 time slot; the class is 2 hours 40 minutes and I was struggling to stay awake. If you do though, just know it gets better. I hated the class originally but once we started prototyping and stuff it was a lot of fun and I was not tired during the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
A lot of what I learned was from phases of the engineering design process.
For one, I learned several different methods to brainstorm ideas. I don't remember the formal name, but one involved dividing our solution into parts, and then all members going in a circle for several minutes thinking of any possible idea for that part. This was a much more systematic way to brainstorm than what I was originally thinking, and there was a big emphasis on being outlandish with ideas. In fact, one of the ideas that I initially thought was unrealistic and not worth considering, solenoid valves, became our final solution.I also learned how to put these ideas together and rank the resulting solution combinations through a Pugh matrix. Again, coming in, my approach would have just been to look at each and every solution qualitatively and see which one "made the most sense," but this was a much more systematic, objective, evidence-based way to identify a solution that best met our design criteria.Finally, I also learned to write technical memos, including the overall style of formal, informative writing, the format (top-down, most-important findings to then specifics), the kind of information to include, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course was focused on developing communication in a manner that allowed groups/teams to efficiently divide tasks amongst each other. Next, the overall engineering design method or how to approach a complex problem was one of the central ideas of the course. Hands-on skills would be 3d design and printing along with circuit soldering, which will (most likely) be very useful to me in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: After this course, I've learned the engineering design process, how to use Pugh scoring and screening matrices, and the safety & use of several tools, including the laser cutter, the 3D printer, and the bandsaw.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Because the class is centered around a team project, much of the learning is self-paced and as-needed to meet the requirements of the prototype. However, professors are willing to share advice and give guidance on projects, when necessary.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors made sure to make the engineering process clear. Every week, we would move on to a new step. Whether that was brainstorming, prototyping, or planning, there was always something to do. I think the openness of the class needs to stay the same because students have a lot of freedom, but the professors still give us enough assignments were we stay on track and do not get far behind.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class is primarily composed of one client-given project that you and your group of 3-5 works on over the course of the entire semester. The first 6-ish weeks are composed of learning solution research and brainstorming skills in order to develop your proposed solution. The next 7-ish weeks are dedicated to hands-on work and prototyping your solution. The class very much has a "figure it out" mentality, which I do think is a fairly good representation of what engineering is. I felt like I was able to learn a lot of skills because I was forced just to try things. The other learning in the class came in the form of two "ToolBits" modules at the beginning of the year, that taught us how to use some of the equipment in the engineering spaces, and also in the form of weekly videos and quizzes that teach us some conceptual engineering concepts.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that the prototyping stage of the class could come earlier. My group had to pivot our chosen solution, almost right at the beginning of the prototyping process, because it was only after we started prototyping that we realized that our solution was unachievable. I feel like if we were allowed to start working on some low-fidelity/medium fidelity prototypes earlier, perhaps still during the brainstorming process, it would make understanding the problem better and would lessen the stress near the end of the semester. Additionally, many of the students around me became very uninvested in the class as we continued to work on the brainstorming and conceptual aspects for such a long time. I think that introducing the hands on work earlier could help make it more intellectually stimulating in that way, as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Systematic Problem-Solving: I learned to approach complex design challenges methodically, particularly through tools like Pugh matrices and pairwise comparison charts. These methods taught me how to evaluate multiple solutions objectively, prioritize criteria, and make informed design decisions based on data rather than intuition alone.Collaboration and Client Engagement: The course emphasized the importance of teamwork and client-centered design. I developed skills in effectively communicating with clients to understand their needs and integrating their feedback into the design process, which mirrored real-world engineering practices.Prototyping and Iterative Testing: I gained hands-on experience with prototyping, including creating and refining a physical model based on testing and feedback. This iterative approach highlighted the value of testing hypotheses, identifying flaws, and making incremental improvements to achieve a functional and user-friendly product.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to work dynamically with a team. I improved my communicating skills and other soft skills, such as giving engineering presentations.
2. I gained many technical skills throughout the course of the semester. Through the tool bits I learned how to design and 3d print and how to laser cut and use the acrylic bender.
3. I learned a lot about the engineering design process. I learned how to brainstorm, ideate solutions, prototype and test. I learned that engineering requires more than simply building a product and has more steps to it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My instructor and the structure of the components of the course definitely facilitated my learning. My instructor was very interested in my project, and the progress of our group. The class was clearly laid out in several different phases, and there was a process for our project (learning background information, brainstorming, prototyping, testing, etc). I would definitely keep the fundamental structure of the class - working in groups on a semester long project was enjoyable and effective for learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me many insights and skills that I believe are going to be very valuable for me in the future. Other than engineering skills such as soldering, CAD, and laser cutting, I believe I learned some other valuable skills. First, I learned how to work with a team over an extended period of time. This allowed me to develop chemistry with my team and navigate interpersonal situations as they regard in-class activities. Secondly, I learned how to write technical memos, which I believe is an essential skill for any engineer looking to summarize any part of the engineering design process. Finally, I learned many lessons with organization. This was one of the first classes I have taken in which the instructors implement a more hands-off approach. While this is very helpful, as it gave me a lot of freedom in terms of what I could choose to do in the class, it forced me to be more organized and plan my time more effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot about the engineering design process and how to take a project from a problem to ideas to a final prototype; I would say that this will be my greatest takeaway, as I can apply this knowledge to effectively create further projects
2 Various engineering skills, including CAD, 3D printing, laser-cutting, and more
3. How to work efficiently in a group and how to manage conflict and sharing/splitting responsibilities among group members

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to encounter failure and pivot when facing challenges. My group ran into several errors in our designs and was forced to find creative solutions to solve these challenges. 
2) I learned that when in the initial brainstorming phase it's encouraged to brainstorm several partial ideas that aren't fully thought out or seem reasonable. This way of thinking was new to me as in the past when it came to brainstorming I would spend lots of time trying to develop a singular idea. This method allowed my group and I to come up with several ideas that we wouldn't have thought of before and combine our seemingly crazy ideas into feasible, practical ones. 
3) I learned how to write technical memos which are a form of writing I had never done before in previous engineering courses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I LOVE EGR101! It's a great way to get some hands-on experience and get a glimpse into what it's like to be a practicing engineer and to have a client. It was awesome picking a project, meeting with the client, and seeing the prototype and project through until the end, and then having a final project to see the success and work you've put into the semester. Having a client and a real goal is also super motivating because it's not theoretical and the clients are really coming to you to find a solution and you get to provide that. It's AWESOME! Highly highly recommend and is a great helper to get an idea of if engineering is the right move for you and something you want to pursue for the rest of your college experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course I learned various skills; woodworking, laser-cutting,3-D printing, and wiring. For example, learning about the various method of brain storming was extremely insightful. From doing index cards, to building up from the ideas of others are different forms of brainstorming I had not been previously exposed to. Then as for the stage where as a team we evaluated each solution, the usage of Paugh and scoring matrixes was a new concept I was introduced to. Lastly, the prototyping stage where we learned about low, medium, and high fidelity was really helpful in getting an idea if our prototype was feasible to begin with.

response_text:

3. I learned that you always have to expect something to go wrong even if you feel like your idea is foolproof, and it is important to always be ready to accommodate for these potential issues.

I say that if your project really needs finishing take the class but if your project is pretty complete and/or is used in medical settings talk with your client to see if it would even be feasible.
